The bloom of protest we call the Arab Spring led to profound change across North Africa and the Middle East.
Apparently impervious autocracies cracked under the pressure of marches and demonstrations.
Bleak predictability gave way to transition, sometimes with relative peace, sometimes amid clouds of teargas and even civil war.
Now everywhere across the region, everyone wonders what comes next.
That question means different things in Libya or Syria, where the old regimes hang on, and in Egypt or Tunisia, where the people will elect new governments in just a couple of months.
Expectation and reality vary from country to country.
